item.title: New Switch 2 Voice Command Software Could Pave the Way for DS Ports
item.content:encoded:
Japanese company Hitachi has announced a new voice command software protocol for the Switch 2, and I, for one, am daring to hope it could be used to finally bring old DS games to the system.

As spotted by Automaton Media, the Ruby Spotter software allows developers to incorporate voice command features beyond simply using the microphone for communication. It's actually already available in a number of other places, including "car navigation systems" and "industrial equipment", according to Automaton.

Hitachi's decision to bring the software to the Switch 2 is driven by a desire to create an environment for developers to include "highly flexible operations" for the microphone in their games, including menu selections and issuing in-game commands.

The possibilities are endless; developers could use Hitachi's Ruby Spotter software to allow you to issue commands to troops in a strategy game, for instance, or to communicate with an in-game character, Nintendogs-style.

That might as well bring us onto what I really hope this software can be used for: porting DS games to the Switch 2. Since there's already a robust library of Game Boy Advance games on the Switch Online service, I think the debut of DS titles is way past due.

Games like The Legend of Zelda: The Phantom Hourglass and the aforementioned Nintendogs used the Nintendo DS' microphone as part of their gameplay, and Hitachi's Ruby Spotter could allow Nintendo to bring those games (which are otherwise unavailable) to the Switch 2.

As it stands, there are tons of DS games, including the ones I've mentioned, that you'll need to turn to the second-hand market to enjoy, and so this would seem like the perfect opportunity to port them to modern systems. Come on, Nintendo. You know it makes sense.

We'll hopefully see developers starting to use this software in games before long. Stay tuned for more.
